revision.text:
{{Use American English|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2011}} {{Infobox military unit |unit_name= 325th Air Division <center>[[File:Continental Air Command.png|60px]]</center> |image=[[File:325planofwork.jpg|290px]] |caption=The 325th printed over two million photos a month |dates= 1944â€“1945; 1947-1949 |country={{flag|United States|23px}} |allegiance= |branch={{air force|USA}} |type= |role=[[aerial reconnaissance|Reconnaissance]] |size= |command_structure=[[Fourth Air Force]] |current_commander= |garrison= |ceremonial_chief= |colonel_of_the_regiment= |nickname= |patron= |motto= |colors= |march= |mascot= |battles= [[World War II]] |notable_commanders= Brigadier General [[Elliott Roosevelt]], 1944, 1945 |anniversaries= |decorations= |battle_honours= }} The '''325th Air Division''' is an inactive [[United States Air Force]] unit. Its last assignment was with [[Fourth Air Force]] at [[Hamilton Air Force Base]], California, where it was inactivated on 27 June 1949.
The unit was first organized as the '''325th Photographic Wing''' during [[World War II]] in England, where it took over the assets of a provisional wing that had been organized earlier in the year. The wing managed the [[aerial reconnaissance|photographic reconnaissance]] units of [[Eighth Air Force]] until the end of the war.
It was reactivated as the '''325th Reconnaissance Wing''' in 1947 and was assigned three subordinate groups in the western United States. It became the '''325th Air Division''' in 1948, but was inactivated in a general reorganization of reserve units in 1949.
==History==
===World War II=== The origins of the '''325th Photographic Wing''' can be traced to early 1944 when Colonel [[Elliott Roosevelt]] arrived in the United Kingdom to study and report on weather reconnaissance and photographic reconnaissance there. On the basis of his report, [[Eighth Air Force]] formed a provisional unit, the 8th Reconnaissance Wing (Provisional) at [[RAF Cheddington]] on 18 February 1944 with Col. Roosevelt as its commander.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.airforcehistoryindex.org/data/000/109/770.xml |last1=|first1=|title=Abstract, Volume 1 History 8 Reconnaissance Wing (Provisional) Feb-May 1944|date=|publisher=Air Force History Index|deadurl=no |accessdate=24 March 2014}}</ref> The wing moved to [[RAF High Wycombe]] a few months later. During the preparation for [[Operation Overlord]], the Normandy invasion, the wing flew the first advanced aerial weather scouting missions for strategic bombardment missions. The wing also flew Eighth Air Force's first night photographic missions and flew shuttle reconnaissance missions to both the Mediterranean Theater and to the Soviet Union.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.airforcehistoryindex.org/data/000/109/772.xml |last1=|first1=|title=Abstract, Volume 1 History 8 Reconnaissance Wing (Provisional) June 1944|date=|publisher=Air Force History Index|deadurl=no |accessdate=24 March 2014}}</ref>
[[File:325coverphoto.jpg|Unit yearbook cover, published in 1945|thumb]] On 8 August 1944 the organization was made permanent and the 325th replaced the 8th as the headquarters for Eighth Air Force's photographic and weather [[aerial reconnaissance|reconnaissance]] units.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.airforcehistoryindex.org/data/000/109/776.xml |last1=|first1=|title=Abstract, History Volume 1, History 325 Photographic Reconnaissance Wing Aug 1944|date=|publisher=Air Force History Index|deadurl=no |accessdate=24 March 2014}}</ref>
From August 1944 until October 1945 subordinate units of the 325th and, using various aircraft, flew reconnaissance over the waters adjacent to the British Islands and the European continent to obtain photographic and meteorological data for use in the air offensive against Europe and the Allied invasion of the continent.<ref name=325ADfacts/> Its aircraft also provided [[electronic countermeasures]] support to confuse enemy [[air defense]]s during allied attacks.<ref>{{cite book|editor=Maurer, Maurer|title=Air Force Combat Units of World War II|origyear= 1961|url= http://www.airforcehistory.hq.af.mil/Publications/fulltext/af_combat_units_wwii.pdf |edition=reprint|year=1983|publisher=Office of Air Force History|location=Washington, DC|isbn=0-912799-02-1|lccn=61060979|page=76}}</ref> To insure the success of an operation as large as the invasion, allied forces required millions of aerial photographs. The 325th wing base laboratory provided photographs of enemy fortifications and troop dispositions vital to employment of ground forces, while Eighth Air Force daylight precision bombing of industrial and military targets required vast quantities of aerial photographs for target material.<ref name=yearbook>325th Photo Wing Recon Base Laboratory yearbook, published by the unit ca. 1945.</ref>
Wing aircraft collected weather information needed in planning operations, flew night photographic missions to detect enemy activity and operated daylight photographic and mapping missions. The wing also flew photographic missions in support of [[Operation Market Garden]], the airborne attacks in the Netherlands, in September 1944. It also operated closely with tactical units in the [[Battle of the Bulge]] from December 1944 to February 1945.<ref name=325ADfacts>{{cite web |url=http://www.afhra.af.mil/factsheets/factsheet.asp?id=10144 |title=Factsheet 325 Air Division, Reconnaissance |publisher=Air Force Historical Research Agency |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121030115742/http://www.afhra.af.mil/factsheets/factsheet.asp?id=10144 |date=5 October 2007|archivedate=30 October 2012|accessdate=22 March 2014}}</ref>
To fill demands for photographic reproduction, the best available equipment (American and British) was obtained and supply requirements and channels were established. Personnel were furnished from the 1st (later replaced by the 8th) and 2nd Photographic Technical Squadrons. The unified effort by personnel of both squadrons enabled the laboratory to produce two million prints in a single month.<ref name=yearbook/>
The wing participated in Project Dick Tracy, a survey of captured German photographic intelligence material.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.airforcehistoryindex.org/data/000/224/606.xml |last1=Eighth Air Force|first1=|title=Abstract, Project Dick Tracy|date=1 January 1945|publisher=Air Force History Index|deadurl=no |accessdate=24 March 2014}}</ref> The purpose of Dick Tracy was to make German intelligence materials readily available to British and American headquarters.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.airforcehistoryindex.org/data/000/212/234.xml |last1=|first1=|title=Abstract, Part 1, History of the Anglo/American Intelligence Staff|date=1 February 1946|publisher=Air Force History Index|deadurl=no |accessdate=24 March 2014}}</ref> Following the [[surrender of Germany]], its units participated in the final bomb damage assessment of European targets.<ref>Maurer, ''Combat Units'', p. 45</ref>
===Post War Reserves=== The wing was reactivated as a reserve unit under [[Air Defense Command]] (ADC) on 9 April 1947 at [[Hamilton Air Force Base]]. It was assigned reserve reconnaissance units stationed at Hamilton<ref>Maurer. ''Combat Units'', pp. 135-136</ref><ref>Maurer, ''Combat Units''. p. 139</ref> and at [[Hill Air Force Base]], Utah.<ref>Maurer, ''Combat Units''. pp. 137-138</ref> In 1948, when the regular Air Force implemented the [[Hobson Plan|wing base organization system]], the [[wing (military aviation unit)|wing]], along with other multi-base reserve wings was redesignated as an [[Air Division (United States)|air division]].<ref name=325ADfacts/><ref>In the case of the 325th, this also prevented confusion with the regular [[325th Fighter Wing]], which was organized at Hamilton in June 1948. {{cite book|last=Ravenstein|first=Charles A.|title=Air Force Combat Wings, Lineage & Honors Histories 1947-1977|url= http://www.airforcehistory.hq.af.mil/Publications/fulltext/combat_wings.pdf |year=1984|publisher=Office of Air Force History|location=Washington, DC|isbn=0-912799-12-9|page=176}}</ref> The same year [[Continental Air Command]] assumed responsibility for managing reserve and [[Air National Guard]] units from ADC.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.airforcehistoryindex.org/data/000/896/983.xml |last1=|first1=|title=Abstract, Mission Project Closeup, Continental Air Command|date=27 December 1961|publisher=Air Force History Index|deadurl=no |accessdate=24 March 2014}}</ref>
The 325th participated in routine reserve training with its assigned trainer aircraft and supervised the training of its three assigned groups until it was inactivated in June 1949 when the reserves adopted the wing base organization system. Most of its equipment and personnel were used to form the [[349th Troop Carrier Wing]], which was simultaneously activated at Hamilton.<ref name=325ADfacts/><ref>Ravenstein, p. 184</ref>
==Lineage== * Constituted as the '''325th Photographic Wing''', Reconnaissance on 17 July 1944 : Activated on 9 August 1944 : Redesignated '''325th Reconnaissance Wing''' on 26 June 1945 : Inactivated on 20 October 1945 * Activated in the reserve on 9 April 1947 : Redesignated '''325th Air Division''', Reconnaissance on 16 April 1948 : Inactivated on 27 June 1949<ref name=325ADfacts/>
===Assignments=== * [[Eighth Air Force]], 9 August 1944 * [[VIII Fighter Command]], 16 July 1945 â€“ 20 October 1945 * [[Fourth Air Force]], 9 April 1947 â€“ 27 June 1949<ref name=325ADfacts/>
===Components=== '''Groups''' * [[7th Reconnaissance Group]] : 9 August 1944 â€“ 18 October 1945 * [[25th Bombardment Group]] : 6 October 1944-c. 23 July 1945 * [[68th Reconnaissance Group]] : 9 April 1947 â€“ 27 June 1949 * [[70th Reconnaissance Group]] : 26 April 1947 â€“ 27 June 1949 * [[72nd Reconnaissance Group]] : 12 July 1947 â€“ 27 June 1949<ref name=325ADfacts/>
'''Squadrons''' * 1st Photographic Technical Squadron: 8 August 1944 - c. 5 November 1944<ref name=yearbook/> * 2d Photographic Technical Squadron: 8 August 1944 - c. 17 August 1945<ref name=yearbook/><ref name=Apr45>{{cite web |url= http://www.airforcehistoryindex.org/data/000/109/789.xml |last1=|first1=|title=Abstract, History Volume 3, History 325 Photographic Reconnaissance Wing Apr 1945|date=|publisher=Air Force History Index|deadurl=no |accessdate=24 March 2014}}</ref> * 8th Photographic Technical Squadron: c. 5 November 1944 - c. 8 October 1945<ref name=yearbook/> * 26th Station Complement Squadron: 1944 - 1945<ref name=Apr45/><ref name=Feb45>{{cite web |url= http://www.airforcehistoryindex.org/data/000/109/789.xml |last1=|first1=|title=Abstract, History Volume 3, History 325 Photographic Reconnaissance Wing Feb 1945|date=|publisher=Air Force History Index|deadurl=no |accessdate=24 March 2014}}</ref> * [[652d Bombardment Squadron]] (Heavy, Weather Reconnaissance): 6 January 1945 â€“ 12 October 1945<ref>325th Air Division Factsheet. But {{cite book|editor=Maurer, Maurer|title=Combat Squadrons of the Air Force, World War II|origyear=1969|url= http://www.airforcehistory.hq.af.mil/Publications/fulltext/combat_sq_of_the_af_wwii.pdf |edition= reprint|year=1982|publisher=Office of Air Force History|location=Washington, DC|isbn=0-405-12194-6|oclc=72556|lccn=70605402|pages=696}} states that the 652d was assigned to [[1st Air Division]] and [[3d Air Division]] during this period.</ref> * [[653d Bombardment Squadron]] (Light, Weather Reconnaissance): 5 September 1945 â€“ 11 October 1945<ref name=325ADfacts/>
'''Units''' * 3d AAF Combat Camera Unit, 8 August 1944 - 6 February 1945<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.afhra.af.mil/factsheets/factsheet.asp?id=15994 |last1=Kane|first1=Robert B.|title=Factsheet 3 Combat Camera Squadron |date=6 April 2012|publisher=Air Force Historical Research Agency|deadurl=no |accessdate=24 March 2014}}</ref> * 8th AAF Combat Camera Unit, 8 August 1944 - c. 20 October 1945
'''Arms and Services with the Army Air Forces''' * Company B, 942d Engineer Aviation Topographic Battalion: 1945<ref name=Feb45/>
===Stations=== * RAF High Wycombe (Station 101), England, 9 August 1944 â€“ 20 October 1945 * [[Hamilton Air Force Base|Hamilton Field (later Hamilton AFB)]], California, 9 April 1947 â€“ 27 June 1949<ref name=325ADfacts/>
===Aircraft=== {{div col|3}} * [[Boeing B-17 Flying Fortress]], 1944â€“1945 * [[Consolidated B-24 Liberator]], 1944â€“1945 * [[North American B-25 Mitchell]], 1944â€“1945 * [[Martin B-26 Marauder]], 1944â€“1945 * [[Lockheed F-5 Lighting]], 1944â€“1945 * [[Stinson L-5]], 1944â€“1945 * [[Lockheed P-38 Lightning]], 1944â€“1945 * [[North American P-51 Mustang]], 1944â€“1945 * [[Supermarine Spitfire]], 1944â€“1945 * [[de Havilland Mosquito PR Mk. XVI]], 1945 * [[North American AT-6 Texan]], 1947â€“1949 * [[Beechcraft AT-7 Navigator]], 1947â€“1949 * [[Beechcraft AT-11 Kansan]], 1947â€“1949<ref name=325ADfacts/> {{div col end}}
===Campaigns=== {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#efefef" ! Campaign Streamer ! Campaign ! Dates ! Notes |- |[[File:European-African-Middle Eastern Campaign Medal streamer.png|200px]]||Northern France||8 August 1944 â€“ 14 September 1944||325th Photographic Wing<ref name=Maurer325RW>Maurer, ''Combat Units'', p. 426</ref> |- |[[File:European-African-Middle Eastern Campaign Medal streamer.png|200px]]||Rhineland||15 September 1944 â€“ 21 March 1945||325th Photographic Wing<ref name="Maurer325RW"/> |- |[[File:European-African-Middle Eastern Campaign Medal streamer.png|200px]]||Ardennes-Alsace||16 December 1944 â€“ 25 January 1945||325th Photographic Wing<ref name="Maurer325RW"/> |- |[[File:European-African-Middle Eastern Campaign Medal streamer.png|200px]]||Central Europe||22 March 1944 â€“ 21 May 1945||325th Photographic Wing<ref name="Maurer325RW"/> |}
